title: blank identifier in declarations is very confusing
body:
by **eapache**: 
Context:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/25466356/how-to-implement-method/25467076
http://play.golang.org/p/Hz1wygtN5G

The go spec requires compilers to accept and ignore declarations of functions and
interfaces using "_" (the blank identifier). Specifically:

"The blank identifier may be used like any other identifier in a declaration, but
it does not introduce a binding and thus is not declared."

This is *very* confusing. I believe it would be simpler and more understandable if
compilers were required to outright reject (with an error messages) attempt to define
methods named "_" rather than have them mysteriously not work.
